26.text: Encounter  drilled  only  110  of  its  planned  250  aircore  holes  due  to  extremely  muddy  conditions.

27.text: Radiometric logging was carried out on the aircore holes.  Drilling successfully extended the area of

28.text: the  known  Centipede  deposit  approximately  150m  to  the  northeast  onto  the  Lake  Way  JV

29.text: tenement.    At  a  100ppm  U3O8  cut-off,  the  mineralisation  extends  over  900m  along  the  south

30.text: western margin of the tenement boundary.

32.text: Work conducted during this reporting period has determined that the Wiluna South project has the

33.text: potential to host a significant uranium resource.  The realisation of this potential will be followed up

20.text: The  project  is  accessed  from  Kalgoorlie,  550km  to  the  south,  via  the  sealed  Goldfields

21.text: Highway to Wiluna.  Final access is provided by well-maintained station tracks that extend to

22.text: the western edge of the project (Figure 1 & 4).  The terrain within the Wiluna South Project

23.text: area comprises a broad flat expanse of saline playa (Lake Way).  Due to muddy conditions,

24.text: the  lake  rarely  enables  access  using  standard  exploration  vehicles  (Figure  2  &  3).    The

25.text: physiography is dominated by flat to gently undulating soil covered plains and isolated low

26.text: sand dunes.  Vegetation is non-existent on Lake Way itself, while the adjacent shoreline is

27.text: dominated by low salt-tolerant shrubs interspersed with patches of sparse acacia woodland.

28.text: Annual  grasses  are  associated  with  clay  and  loam  soils  around  the  lake  fringe,  and

29.text: perennial spinifex grass occurs in sandier soils and dunes.

60.text: Table 1: Wiluna South Project - Tenement Summary

text:
The  project  is  accessed  from  Kalgoorlie,  550km  to  the  south,  via  the  sealed  Goldfields 
 Highway to Wiluna.  Final access is provided by well-maintained station tracks that extend to 
 the western edge of the project (Figure 1 & 4).  The terrain within the Wiluna South Project 
 area comprises a broad flat expanse of saline playa (Lake Way).  Due to muddy conditions, 
 the  lake  rarely  enables  access  using  standard  exploration  vehicles  (Figure  2  &  3).    The 
 physiography is dominated by flat to gently undulating soil covered plains and isolated low 
 sand dunes.  Vegetation is non-existent on Lake Way itself, while the adjacent shoreline is 
 dominated by low salt-tolerant shrubs interspersed with patches of sparse acacia woodland.  
 Annual  grasses  are  associated  with  clay  and  loam  soils  around  the  lake  fringe,  and 
 perennial spinifex grass occurs in sandier soils and dunes.

42.text: The above mentioned joint venture partners explored the northern shores of Lake Way for

43.text: sediment hosted uranium mineralisation between 1976 and 1986.  The area explored occurs

44.text: adjacent  to  Avoca’s  northern  tenement  boundary.    A  comprehensive  program  was

45.text: completed  which  included  both  ground  and  airborne  radiometric  and  magnetic  surveys.

46.text: Anomalous areas were systematically drilled which resulted in the discovery of a significant

47.text: uranium resource termed Lake Way located 4km north of Avoca tenure (Collins, 1980).  A

48.text: Measured,  Indicated  and  Inferred  resource  of  5000  tonnes  grading  0.68kg/t  U3O8  was

49.text: defined.    A  full  feasibility  study  concluded  that  the  deposit  was  uneconomic  given  the

50.text: prevailing political environment and metal prices at the time.

 operations  located  further  south.    A  number  of  RC  holes  were  drilled  for  piezometer  test

21.text: The  Wiluna  South  Project  is  located  near  the  eastern  margin  of  the  Archaean  Norseman-

22.text: Wiluna greenstone belt that forms a major constituent of the Eastern Goldfields Province of

25.text: The  Archaean  succession  in  the  Wiluna  district  is  approximately  20km  wide,  sandwiched

26.text: between massive coarse grained biotite granites.  The stratigraphy strikes 330o and dips to

27.text: the east at between 60o and 70o.  The Archaean sequence is metamorphosed to greenschist

28.text: facies.    The  Archaean  basement  is  not  exposed  anywhere  within  the  tenure  and  the

29.text: underlying geology has been extrapolated between exposures in the north and south using

30.text: aeromagnetic  data  (Langford  et  al.,  1997).    The  project  area  comprises  three  main

31.text: stratigraphic  units.    The  eastern  unit  is  underlain  by  a  foliated  granite-gneiss  with  minor

32.text: inclusions of amphibolitic mafic lenses.  The central unit is composed predominantly of mafic

33.text: volcanic rocks intercalated with minor foliated granitoid rock and metamorphosed ultramafic

34.text: sequences.  The western unit represents the southern strike extensions of the Wiluna mine

35.text: sequence.    This  sequence  is  dominated  by  weakly  metamorphosed,  high  magnesium

36.text: basalts with minor conformable felsic volcanic rocks and intrusive quartz dolerite sills.

38.text: The entire project occurs beneath the Cainozoic sediments and playa deposits of Lake Way.

text:
The  Wiluna  South  Project  is  located  near  the  eastern  margin  of  the  Archaean  Norseman-
 Wiluna greenstone belt that forms a major constituent of the Eastern Goldfields Province of 
 the Yilgarn Craton, Western Australia (Figure 4). 
 The  Archaean  succession  in  the  Wiluna  district  is  approximately  20km  wide,  sandwiched 
 between massive coarse grained biotite granites.  The stratigraphy strikes 330o and dips to 
 the east at between 60o and 70o.  The Archaean sequence is metamorphosed to greenschist 
 facies.    The  Archaean  basement  is  not  exposed  anywhere  within  the  tenure  and  the 
 underlying geology has been extrapolated between exposures in the north and south using 
 aeromagnetic  data  (Langford  et  al.,  1997).    The  project  area  comprises  three  main 
 stratigraphic  units.    The  eastern  unit  is  underlain  by  a  foliated  granite-gneiss  with  minor 
 inclusions of amphibolitic mafic lenses.  The central unit is composed predominantly of mafic 
 volcanic rocks intercalated with minor foliated granitoid rock and metamorphosed ultramafic 
 sequences.  The western unit represents the southern strike extensions of the Wiluna mine 
 sequence.    This  sequence  is  dominated  by  weakly  metamorphosed,  high  magnesium 
 basalts with minor conformable felsic volcanic rocks and intrusive quartz dolerite sills.   
 The entire project occurs beneath the Cainozoic sediments and playa deposits of Lake Way.

40.text: clay  deposits  and  calcareous  sand  dunes  located  along  the  shores.    These  recent

41.text: sediments directly overlie Archaean basement rocks of the Yilgarn Craton and usually vary

42.text: in thickness between 1 and 10 metres, however deeper channels do exist.

clay  deposits  and  calcareous  sand  dunes  located  along  the  shores.    These  recent 
 sediments directly overlie Archaean basement rocks of the Yilgarn Craton and usually vary 
 in thickness between 1 and 10 metres, however deeper channels do exist.

17.text: The Lake Way and Centipede uranium deposits are clearly associated with tributary channel

18.text: deltas entering the primary Lake Way palaeo-drainage system. This is suggested to be due

19.text: to subtle changes in groundwater chemistry and saturation levels of potassium, uranium and

20.text: vanadium responsible for carnotite precipitation.  Mineralisation in uranium-calcrete-hosted

21.text: deposits is carnotite, which occurs along fractures, bedding planes, and in carbonate quartz

22.text: clays  and  grits,  as  disseminations  throughout  a  carbonate  matrix  (Crabb  et  al.,  1984).

23.text: Should  this  prove  correct,  then  ‘deltaic’  environments  along  the  lake  shoreline  should  be

24.text: considered to represent higher priority exploration targets.

28.text: Radiometric anomalies define the uranium concentrations at both Lake Way and Centipede.

29.text: Lease  E53/1010  covers  the  ground  between  these  two  deposits  and  shows  radiometric

30.text: anomalies on the lake surface over a distance of approximately 12km.  These radiometric

31.text: anomalies may be interpreted as a sinuous channel that persists through E53/1010 beneath

32.text: superficial  lake  sediment  cover,  effectively  linking  the  Lake  Way  and  Centipede  deposits

33.text: (Figure  5).    Another  interpretation  is  that  the  migration  of  daughter  products  from  the

34.text: surrounding mineralisation may give rise to spurious displaced anomalies (Cameron, 2005).

35.text: The  lake  margins  and  lake  itself  are  respectively  veneered  by  superficial  lacustrine

36.text: sediments  and  sand  dunes  that  locally  appear  to  largely  mask  the  airborne  uranium

37.text: radiometric response.  The distribution of sand dunes, at least, appears to partially coincide

38.text: with apparently unmineralised areas between the adjacent Centipede deposits.

46.text: Exploration  of  the  Lake  Way  tenements  for  uranium  was  undertaken  by  Encounter  during

47.text: the  reporting  period.    Encounter  completed  a  heritage  survey  of  the  area  and  drilled  110

48.text: aircore  holes  (Appendix  1).    Radiometric  logging  was  carried  out  on  the  aircore  holes

text:
Uranium Geology at Lake Ways 
 The Lake Way and Centipede uranium deposits are clearly associated with tributary channel 
 deltas entering the primary Lake Way palaeo-drainage system. This is suggested to be due 
 to subtle changes in groundwater chemistry and saturation levels of potassium, uranium and 
 vanadium responsible for carnotite precipitation.  Mineralisation in uranium-calcrete-hosted 
 deposits is carnotite, which occurs along fractures, bedding planes, and in carbonate quartz 
 clays  and  grits,  as  disseminations  throughout  a  carbonate  matrix  (Crabb  et  al.,  1984).  
 Should  this  prove  correct,  then  ‘deltaic’  environments  along  the  lake  shoreline  should  be 
 considered to represent higher priority exploration targets. 
 Radiometric Anomalies 
 Radiometric anomalies define the uranium concentrations at both Lake Way and Centipede. 
 Lease  E53/1010  covers  the  ground  between  these  two  deposits  and  shows  radiometric 
 anomalies on the lake surface over a distance of approximately 12km.  These radiometric 
 anomalies may be interpreted as a sinuous channel that persists through E53/1010 beneath 
 superficial  lake  sediment  cover,  effectively  linking  the  Lake  Way  and  Centipede  deposits 
 (Figure  5).    Another  interpretation  is  that  the  migration  of  daughter  products  from  the 
 surrounding mineralisation may give rise to spurious displaced anomalies (Cameron, 2005).  
 The  lake  margins  and  lake  itself  are  respectively  veneered  by  superficial  lacustrine 
 sediments  and  sand  dunes  that  locally  appear  to  largely  mask  the  airborne  uranium 
 radiometric response.  The distribution of sand dunes, at least, appears to partially coincide 
 with apparently unmineralised areas between the adjacent Centipede deposits.

 the  reporting  period.    Encounter  completed  a  heritage  survey  of  the  area  and  drilled  110 
 aircore  holes  (Appendix  1).    Radiometric  logging  was  carried  out  on  the  aircore  holes

 A  field  inspection  of  Encounter’s  program  impacting  the  foreshore  confirmed  that  these

18.text: material was identified during the field inspection.

 Encounter  undertook  uranium  exploration  on  behalf  of  the  Lake  Way  Joint  Venture  during 
 2006  and  early  2007.    Three  calcrete-style  uranium  mineralisation  targets  were  identified 
 The western shore of the lake, adjacent to Nova Energy’s Centipede uranium 
 The eastern shore of Lake Way, previously unexplored for uranium. 
 The radiometric signature that appears to link Nova Energy’s Centipede and 
 Lake Way uranium resources. 
 A total of 250 drill holes were planned, with only 110 drill holes completed.  Aircore drilling 
 was only partly completed by February 2007 adjacent to the Centipede resource (Target 1) 
 and for the northern section of the eastern Lake Way shoreline (Target 2).  The remainder of 
 the planned exploration, on the eastern shore (Target 2) and along the centre of Lake Way 
 (Target  3),  was  abandoned  due  to  wet  lake  conditions  from  seasonal  tropical  rains, 
 particularly Cyclone George.  The drill rig used for this program was specially designed for 
 salt lake work but still had access and mobility problems on the lake surface (Figure 6). 
 Target 1: Exploration adjacent to the Centipede resource 
 Target 1 was designed to test an area of the lake along the interpreted northern extension of 
 Nova Energy’s Centipede uranium resource.  Drilling successfully extended the area of the 
 known Centipede mineralisation approximately 150m to the northeast onto the Lake Way JV 
 tenement.  At a 100ppm U3O8 cutoff, the mineralisation extends over 900m along the south 
 western  margin  of  the  tenement  boundary.    The  interpreted  outline  of  mineralisation  is 
 shown in Figure 7 with best results in Table 2 below.
